content:
Thunderbird, by design, does not have your primary password to give to you. That is for your security. If it provided it to you, then it could provide to anyone. This is no joke. To reset your PC, do these steps:

  1. Choose Tools > Developer Tools > Error Console
  2. Paste the expression: 
  openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xhtml")
  1. then, press the Evaluate button. That will open a dialog asking you if you want to reset your password. If Evaluate is not seen, press enter key.
  2. When prompted, press the Reset button.

This removes all account passwords, which must then be reentered.
creator: davidsk

content: TB menu > Account Settings > account > Email Address.
creator: siffemoz

content: Right click the folder, select properties and check the folder is included when getting mail.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: If everything is the same except the email address, just enter correct email address, replacing the current one in the server settings pane, the account pane, and the SMTP server pane. Thunderbird will likely restart.
creator: davidsk

content: Usually, you can select all messages in one folder, select the COPY option to copy to another folder and then delete from original folder. I emphasize 'copy' because if the account is IMAP, the transfer is over the internet. If a POP account, highlighting all and moving should suffice
creator: davidsk

content: Can I drag and drop entire folders, or won't that work? both boxes are on IMAP
creator: iksiks1986

content: Or should I download everything to my hard drive and transfer it to another box?
creator: iksiks1986

content: Drag&drop conceptually works, but there may be irrecoverable data loss. That is why I suggested COPY. Remember, since they are IMAP, the actual data are on the server, not on the PC. Copying offline to another folder bypasses the process.
creator: davidsk

content:
You cannot do this from within Thunderbird. You must do this with your email provider. You can then either edit your password in Thunderbird to reflect your newly acquired password, or delete the old password in Thunderbird, after which you should be prompted to enter and save the new one.

Keep in mind that your password may be stored twice - once for the outgoing (IMAP or POP3) server, and once for the outgoing (SMTP) server.

content: You'll have to login to your email account via web browser to change the password for your account. If you lost your account password check with your email provider about password reset options. Once you do have a working password Thunderbird will prompt you for the password when it's needed. You can then tell Thunderbird to remember the password, so that you won't have to type it again and again every time it's needed.
creator: christ1

content:
For Thunderbird to remember your password you'd need to check the corresponding box at the password prompt. For modern OAuth2 authentication Thunderbird does not remember your account password, but an OAuth authentication token instead. There is no point not to remember that, because you'd have to go through the authentication process every time you log on to your account.

sometimes I open thunderbird and cancel the request for it to download messages

When Thunderbird didn't remember your password, then obviously this will prevent you from getting new mail.

You may also want to set a primary password, which protects any remembered account passwords. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password
creator: christ1

content:
Try this idea: Have you thought of starting Thunderbird in Offline Mode ? It might work for you.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to Network & Disk Space
  • click on the 'Offline' button'
  • You can set up the Manual state when starting up as 'Offline'
  • click on 'OK'

Then you can go into 'Online mode' when you want to download or send mail. In bottom Status bar on far left is the quick method to swap between Online/Offline, so after downloading mail you could go back into Offline mode. Then you can allow it to auto check to get prompt.

content:
I want to be able to switch a large chunk of my email archive "off" so it doesn't automatically load when Thunderbird launches

I don't think that's possible, and it wouldn't make any sense to me. Thunderbird doesn't have a problem with large profiles, and it doesn't load all messages in all folders at startup. However, the no. of messages in a single folder can be more problematic. So you may have a problem with very large folders, and with a large no. of messages in the Local Folders account. It would be better to split an archive in multiple smaller folders with less messages in them, e.g. on a yearly basis.

Also, you may want to create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. At best, anti-virus software can slow down Thunderbird. At worst, it can corrupt mail files and cause data loss.

Wrt the high memory usage, some quick items:

  • Try Help > Troubleshoot Mode.
  • Do you have any folders where you've seen problems?
  • Do you have many newsgroup or rss accounts, or virtual folders?

For a longer list, see https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Testing:Memory_Usage_Problems
creator: christ1

content: Just a comment here: In gmail, all mail is in Allmail, and that can be confusing. If you find the mail online and the headers show the recipient, then the message was sent. Also, with Gmail, a particular message may be cataloged in multiple labels (folders). The general recommendation in Thunderbird is to NOT use the Allmail folder: it causes confusion, doubles disk space, doubles transfer resource usage. On your specific issue, I do not know why the messages do not appear where you expected them.

content:
Hola Usted escribió en el foro en Español, o si usted utiliza el Thunderbird en español su consulta se redirige al foro en español. El error 528 en clientes de correo generalmente indica un fallo en la autenticación SMTP, donde el servidor no reconoce las credenciales proporcionadas, o un problema de tiempo de espera (timeout) donde el par remoto no responde. Las soluciones incluyen verificar usuario/contraseña o revisar la configuración de seguridad

Saludos

content: Open the account on outlook.com, under Settings, Mail, Forwarding & IMAP, check that IMAP is enabled.
creator: sfhowes

content:
The -- has been around for decades as a separator between text and signature. The intent was a pseudo-standard that allowed email clients to automatically remove sigs on replies to avoid clutter of seeing a sig multiple times on a long thread. More info on that is here: https://mailformat.dan.info/trailers/sigblocks.html

You can permanently remove it from instructions on this site below:

https://kb.mozillazine.org/Signatures_-_Thunderbird#Removing_the_signature_separator
creator: davidsk

content:
Oh, okay. Been using Outlook and hardly used it (no heavy office use). Thought it was a weird Thunderbird feature.

I did find an article that said something about "mail.strip_sig_on_reply" but you know the actual proper setting: mail.identity.default.suppress_signature_separator

Thanks for the assistance David and the back info. If I ever come across "--" again, I'll know what it's for.

david said
The -- has been around for decades as a separator between text and signature. The intent was a pseudo-standard that allowed email clients to automatically remove sigs on replies to avoid clutter of seeing a sig multiple times on a long thread. More info on that is here: https://mailformat.dan.info/trailers/sigblocks.html You can permanently remove it from instructions on this site below: https://kb.mozillazine.org/Signatures_-_Thunderbird#Removing_the_signature_separator
creator: bradsmithsite

content: I was glad to assist.
creator: davidsk

content: Note, standard signature separator requires a trailing space.

content: To clarify, the email provider is the one that does not recognize the password. Thunderbird is only the messenger. This can happen if the account is setup incorrectly, or where the account requires a special password for email clients (such as Gmail).
creator: davidsk

content: Make sure cookies are allowed in Thunderbird. Also make sure no other service is occupying TCP port 80, e.g. a local web server.
creator: christ1

I haven't noticed a similar problem anywhere else so it's unlikely to be a generic shortcut problem.
